items.title: Between-Group Variance Dominance
items.content:
355: :label: cor-between-group-dominance
356: 
357: For a high-error swarm satisfying $V_{\text{struct}} > R^2_{\text{spread}}$, the between-group variance term dominates:
358: 
359: $$
360: f_I f_J \|\mu_x(I_k) - \mu_x(J_k)\|^2 \geq c_{\text{sep}}(\varepsilon) V_{\text{struct}}
361: 
362: $$
363: 
364: for some N-uniform constant $c_{\text{sep}}(\varepsilon) > 0$.
365: 
366: **Proof:**
367: 
368: This follows from the Phase-Space Packing Lemma (Lemma 6.4.1 in [03_cloning](03_cloning), line 2409).
369: 
370: By the clustering construction (Definition 6.3, line 2351), the high-error set $H_k$ consists of outlier clusters with high between-cluster variance contribution. Since $I_k \subseteq H_k$ (target set is subset of high-error), the spatial separation between $I_k$ and $J_k$ (which contains all low-error walkers $L_k$) must be substantial.
371: 
372: Specifically, from the Phase-Space Packing Lemma with $d_{\text{close}} = D_{\text{diam}}(\varepsilon) = c_d \varepsilon$:
373: 
374: If $\text{Var}_h(S_k) > R^2_{\text{pack}} := \varepsilon^2 / 2$, then not all pairs can be close in phase space. This forces:
375: 
376: $$
377: \|\mu_x(I_k) - \mu_x(J_k)\|^2 \geq c_{\text{pack}}(\varepsilon) \text{Var}_x(S_k)
378: 
379: $$
380: 
381: for some geometric constant $c_{\text{pack}}(\varepsilon) > 0$.
382: 
383: Using $\text{Var}_x(S_k) \geq V_{\text{struct}} / (1 + \lambda_v)$ (position component of hypocoercive variance) and $f_I f_J \geq f_{UH} (1 - f_{UH}) \geq f_{UH}/2$ (for $f_{UH} \leq 1/2$):
384: 
385: $$
386: f_I f_J \|\mu_x(I_k) - \mu_x(J_k)\|^2 \geq \frac{f_{UH}}{2} \cdot c_{\text{pack}}(\varepsilon) \cdot \frac{V_{\text{struct}}}{1 + \lambda_v} =: c_{\text{sep}}(\varepsilon) V_{\text{struct}}
387: 
388: $$

items.title: Quadratic Scaling for Separated Swarms
items.content:
1087: :label: cor-quadratic-scaling-wasserstein
1088: 
1089: For two swarms $S_1, S_2$ with barycenters $\bar{x}_1, \bar{x}_2$ at distance $L = \|\bar{x}_1 - \bar{x}_2\|$, consider the synchronous coupling where walker $i \in S_1$ (outlier) clones from walker $\pi(i) \in S_2$ (companion).
1090: 
1091: The global barycenter is $\bar{x} \approx \frac{\bar{x}_1 + \bar{x}_2}{2}$ (assuming equal swarm sizes).
1092: 
1093: **Then:**
1094: 
1095: $$
1096: D_{ii} - D_{ji} \approx L^2
1097: $$
1098: 
1099: More precisely:
1100: 
1101: $$
1102: D_{ii} - D_{ji} \geq \frac{L^2}{2} - C_{\text{err}}
1103: $$
1104: 
1105: where $C_{\text{err}} = O(L R_H + R_H^2)$ for separated swarms with $L \gg R_H$.
1106: 
1107: **Proof:**
1108: 
1109: By Proposition {prf:ref}`prop-exact-distance-change`:
1110: 
1111: $$
1112: D_{ii} - D_{ji} = -(N-1)\|x_{2,\pi(i)} - x_{1,i}\|^2 - 2N\langle x_{2,\pi(i)} - x_{1,i}, x_{1,i} - \bar{x} \rangle
1113: $$
1114: 
1115: **First term (quadratic in $L$):**
1116: 
1117: The distance between outlier in $S_1$ and companion in $S_2$ is approximately:
1118: 
1119: $$
1120: \|x_{2,\pi(i)} - x_{1,i}\| \approx \|\bar{x}_2 - \bar{x}_1\| + O(R_L + R_H) = L + O(R_H)
1121: $$
1122: 
1123: Therefore:
1124: 
1125: $$
1126: \|x_{2,\pi(i)} - x_{1,i}\|^2 \geq L^2 - 2L R_H
1127: $$
1128: 
1129: So:
1130: 
1131: $$
1132: -(N-1)\|x_{2,\pi(i)} - x_{1,i}\|^2 \leq -(N-1)L^2 + 2(N-1)LR_H
1133: $$
1134: 
1135: **Second term (also quadratic!):**
1136: 
1137: The outlier position relative to global barycenter:
1138: 
1139: $$
1140: x_{1,i} - \bar{x} \approx (x_{1,i} - \bar{x}_1) + \left(\bar{x}_1 - \frac{\bar{x}_1 + \bar{x}_2}{2}\right) = (x_{1,i} - \bar{x}_1) + \frac{\bar{x}_1 - \bar{x}_2}{2}
1141: $$
1142: 
1143: The displacement from companion to outlier:
1144: 
1145: $$
1146: x_{2,\pi(i)} - x_{1,i} \approx (\bar{x}_2 - \bar{x}_1) + O(R_H)
1147: $$
1148: 
1149: **Inner product:**
1150: 
1151: $$
1152: \begin{aligned}
1153: \langle x_{2,\pi(i)} - x_{1,i}, x_{1,i} - \bar{x} \rangle &\approx \left\langle \bar{x}_2 - \bar{x}_1, (x_{1,i} - \bar{x}_1) + \frac{\bar{x}_1 - \bar{x}_2}{2} \right\rangle \\
1154: &= \langle \bar{x}_2 - \bar{x}_1, x_{1,i} - \bar{x}_1 \rangle + \left\langle \bar{x}_2 - \bar{x}_1, \frac{\bar{x}_1 - \bar{x}_2}{2} \right\rangle \\
1155: &= \langle \bar{x}_2 - \bar{x}_1, x_{1,i} - \bar{x}_1 \rangle - \frac{L^2}{2}
1156: \end{aligned}
1157: $$
1158: 
1159: **Use Outlier Alignment:** By Lemma {prf:ref}`lem-outlier-alignment`:
1160: 
1161: $$
1162: \langle x_{1,i} - \bar{x}_1, \bar{x}_1 - \bar{x}_2 \rangle \geq \eta R_H L
1163: $$
1164: 
1165: Therefore:
1166: 
1167: $$
1168: \langle \bar{x}_2 - \bar{x}_1, x_{1,i} - \bar{x}_1 \rangle = -\langle x_{1,i} - \bar{x}_1, \bar{x}_1 - \bar{x}_2 \rangle \leq -\eta R_H L
1169: $$
1170: 
1171: So:
1172: 
1173: $$
1174: \langle x_{2,\pi(i)} - x_{1,i}, x_{1,i} - \bar{x} \rangle \leq -\eta R_H L - \frac{L^2}{2}
1175: $$
1176: 
1177: Therefore:
1178: 
1179: $$
1180: -2N\langle x_{2,\pi(i)} - x_{1,i}, x_{1,i} - \bar{x} \rangle \geq 2N\eta R_H L + NL^2
1181: $$
1182: 
1183: **Combine both terms:**
1184: 
1185: $$
1186: D_{ii} - D_{ji} \geq -(N-1)L^2 + 2(N-1)LR_H + 2N\eta R_H L + NL^2
1187: $$
1188: 
1189: $$
1190: = L^2[-(N-1) + N] + 2LR_H[(N-1) + N\eta]
1191: $$
1192: 
1193: $$
1194: = L^2 + 2LR_H[(N-1) + N\eta]
1195: $$
1196: 
1197: For $N$ large and $L \gg R_H$:
1198: 
1199: $$
1200: D_{ii} - D_{ji} \geq L^2 + O(NLR_H)
1201: $$
1202: 
1203: For the Wasserstein-2 distance per pair (dividing by number of pairs), we get:
1204: 
1205: $$
1206: \frac{D_{ii} - D_{ji}}{N} \geq \frac{L^2}{N} + O(LR_H)
1207: $$
1208: 
1209: For the empirical measure contraction, the relevant quantity is the total squared distance, which is $O(NL^2)$, giving:
1210: 
1211: $$
1212: \frac{D_{ii} - D_{ji}}{D_{ii} + D_{jj}} \approx \frac{L^2}{2L^2} = \frac{1}{2} = O(1)
1213: $$

items.content:
1654: :label: cor-total-perturbation
1655: 
1656: The total perturbative contribution to the Stratonovich drift of $V_{\text{total}}$ satisfies:
1657: 
1658: $$
1659: A_{\text{perturb}}(S) \le \epsilon_F K_F(\rho) (V_{\text{total}}(S) + 1) + C_{\text{diff,0}}(\rho) + C_{\text{diff,1}}(\rho) V_{\text{total}}(S)
1660: 
1661: $$
1662: 
1663: where **all constants are ρ-dependent**:
1664: - The adaptive force contributes $O(\epsilon_F V_{\text{total}})$ with coefficient $K_F(\rho)$ (Lemma {prf:ref}`lem-adaptive-force-bounded`)
1665: - The viscous force contributes a negative (stabilizing) term $\le 0$ (Lemma [](#lem-viscous-dissipative))

1667:

1669: 
1670: $$

1672: 
1673: $$

3057: 
3058: $$

items.title: BAOAB Discretization Validity
items.content:
1860: :label: cor-baoab-validity
1861: 
1862: **Hypotheses:** Consider the adaptive Langevin SDE with:
1863: 1. Fitness potential $V_{\text{fit}}[f_k, \rho] \in C^3(\mathcal{X})$ with bounded derivatives (Theorem {prf:ref}`thm-c3-regularity`)
1864: 2. Friction coefficient $\gamma > 0$
1865: 3. Temperature $T > 0$ (or equivalently, noise scale $\sigma > 0$)
1866: 4. Time step $\Delta t$ satisfying the stability criterion:
1867: $$
1868: \Delta t \le \Delta t_{\max}(\rho, \gamma) := \min\left( \frac{1}{2\gamma}, \frac{\rho^{3/2}}{K_{V,3}(\rho)^{1/2}} \right)

1875: 3. **Foster-Lyapunov preservation:** The drift inequality $\mathcal{L}V \le -\lambda V + b$ for the continuous SDE translates to the discrete chain with error $O(\Delta t^3)$

items.title: Explicit Convergence Time
items.content:
2440: :label: cor-explicit-convergence-time
2441: 
2442: From the Foster-Lyapunov condition and geometric ergodicity (Theorem [](#thm-main-convergence)), the **mixing time** to reach $\epsilon$-accuracy in total variation is:
2443: 
2444: $$
2445: t_{\text{mix}}(\epsilon) = O\left( \frac{1}{\kappa_{\text{total}}} \log\left( \frac{C_\pi (1 + V_{\text{total}}(S_0, S_0))}{\epsilon} \right) \right)
2446: $$
2447: 
2448: where $C_\pi$ is the geometric ergodicity constant.
2449: 
2450: **Number of algorithm iterations** required:
2451: 
2452: $$
2453: n_{\text{iter}}(\epsilon) = \left\lceil \frac{t_{\text{mix}}(\epsilon)}{\tau} \right\rceil = O\left( \frac{1}{\kappa_{\text{total}} \tau} \log\left( \frac{C_\pi V(S_0)}{\epsilon} \right) \right)
2454: $$
2455: 
2456: **Explicit parameter dependence**: Using Theorem [](#thm-explicit-total-rate):
2457: 
2458: $$
2459: n_{\text{iter}}(\epsilon) = O\left( \frac{1}{\min\{\kappa_x, \min\{\gamma, c_{\min}\}\tau, \kappa_b\} \cdot \tau} \log\left( \frac{C_\pi V(S_0)}{\epsilon} \right) \right)
2460: $$
